comment: @ADreamingTraveler  It's frightening reading these comments - how easily people are manipulated by CEOs. All these dudes are machines, bordering on sociopathic, trained to deceive, trained to "make impression", trained to make lenient to their causes. You really think there is something that is NOT choreographed? There is not a single thing that is NOT calculated. But still, they are human. And you need to look for these glimpses of humanity that eventually sip through.. in case of this guy, he lost his mask for a sec there when Lex said something positive about Sam wanting to travel to talk to the people about AI and be open to suggestions and he vehemently corrected him: "oh no no, I'm going to travel to talk to the developers"... That's what he truly thinks about you and your opinion on the matter. Too bad he's playing with things he doesn't understand and the consequences might be global. If that's not the most arrogant, egocentrical / sociopath think one might do, I dont know what is. F this guy. He's beefed up version of Zuckenberg.

comment: @BeFourCM  CEOs had to abandon their own beliefs and by extension their souls because of their fiduciary duty - they are no longer entitled to have their own opinion. Everything they say publicly is a function of stock exchange value graph. Due to the aforementioned fiduciary duty, they can even go to jail if they were proven to purposely misrepresent or hurt their business with what they say or what they do. Considering all of this and how much money is all the line, it's baffling anyone takes seriously anything they say. You can only look for the cracks in their masquerade  to find something meaningful about them and glimpses of truth - and his show what usually can be seen - arrogance, narcissism and blind belief in oneself. In case of this guy, also egoism because if something goes very wrong, we are all f*cked. And the optimistic scenario is that labor market map is going to completely change. But hey - he is doing it for our greater good of course! And huge quality of life improvement! To quote SIlicon Valley TV series: "to make the world a better place" ;)

comment:
That's how exponential progress works. During 100 years of 21st century we'll live thru 10000 years of progress at 20th century rate.
Fasten seatbelts, expect things to change a lot and don't forget to enjoy the ride. 😜

Time to 50 million users:
- Airlines 64 years
- Automobiles 62 years
- Telephone 50 years
- Electricity 46 years
- Credit Cards 28 years
- Television 22 years
- ATMs 18 years
- Computers 14 years
- Mobile Phones 12 years
- Internet 7 years

Time to 100 million users:
- Facebook 4.5 years
- Instagram 2.5 years
- TikTok 9 months
- ChatGPT 2 months

comment:
"how would we know if like on Twitter we were mostly having like llms direct the whatever's flowing through that hive mind yeah on Twitter and then perhaps Beyond and then as on Twitter so everywhere else eventually"

AI already directs what is flowing through the hive mind of all social media, and it's a big contributor to the growth in divisiveness. The tweets are not all written by AI, but AI algorithms are selecting between half a billion tweets a day to keep you engaged. And, what keeps us engaged is material that triggers emotionally charged reactions.

comment: In order for AI to be able to produce authentic characters or to analyse historical events, for example "A Nazi Officer from WW2 who hates Jews and loves The Fatherland.", won't it have to be run with the safety off, to even begin to produce or understand realistic dialogue? Our literature is full of abuse, murder, horror and betrayal as a backdrop to reversal and redemption, and pre-censoring our AIs for the sake of safety is likely to reduce their applicability and utility.

comment: Not that I don't appreciate him taking the time to do the interview, but just personally I find a bit disingenuous to say that they're building out in the open considering their more recent profit-driven decisions being cagey about GPT-4, as well as not being totally clear about the actual training dataset used on previous versions. That said, I don't believe it takes away from the innovations achieved with GPT, there's still much to learn in the "report" they released, maybe further learnings can be applied to the leaked lambda model (which was even more caged up) or a new architecture. The future is finally exciting for the layman

comment: 1:37:00 - On creating new job, UBI, eliminating poverty and the Dignity of Work; AI can be the solution to the loneliness problem created by technology, by freeing us all up to talk in a transparent open way. But human nature will drive fearful people together too. People herd into groups and there are brilliant and brutal outcomes. Tim Urban does a good job discussing this in his book "What's Our Problem? A Self Help Book for Societies" worth a listen and view on his "Wait but Why" website.  I think AI will bring us all more understanding about how we interact as a society and why we're facing culture wars right now - but we gotta do it.

comment: Great interview, Lex! I do want to point out that the chess example Sam provided might not be directly applicable to this topic. Chess is a game that people play and watch for entertainment. Companies will always prioritize AI over humans if it means enhancing their skill to generate revenue. For instance, if an ability to play chess is generating revenue for them, they would prioritize using AI over human players.

comment: Am a English language teacher, programmer and tech auther, so was really looking forward to Chat GPT, and tried it out for business, tech, creative writing, 'science' and programming. Fails miserably in the 'intelligence' department, unless you like reading propaganda at the 8th grade level. It is amazing for how fast it can write blocks of code, and that will let India completely take over high- tech, with their lower meat-space human labor cost structure, but call it 'intelligent'? Nope! Call it a 'chat' app? Nope. Call it a stock picker? Nope! Call it a scientific research aide? Nope!
